So now we're on for this year.
So there's a couple of new things I want to share with you all.
So there's an analogy that I used to use saying that Ethereum is the world computer.
I no longer say that.
I think instead, Ethereum is the arena where we can play the positive sum games
that we could not play before.
So for example, take the prisoner's dilemma.
This is a classic game that we're all familiar with.
It's a classic non-cooperative game and you always defect.
In Ethereum, this becomes a positive sum game because before you go do your criminal
criminal thing, you can say, "Oh, I'm going to put on a deposit of, say, a billion
dollars saying, 'If I defect, this money just gets burned.'"
All right.
This is fundamentally new because you're able to move the Nash equilibrium.
And this needs to be like a fundamentally new thing in Ethereum.
So one thing I think would be really interesting to do is to go through a classic game theory
textbook and find all the games that are typically non-cooperative and then say if you
then arm the agents with Ethereum, how many of them now become cooperative games?
And this could be big.
So you're looking for, so there's probably more things like this.
So in short, I think it's the way to think about what Ethereum is good for.
All right.
So here's another thing to think about.
So I'd say the first killer app for Ethereum was just sending integers to each other,
just sending money.
The third one was unfortunately probably the ICO.
But the third, I think, could be parametric insurance.
Now, you probably have not heard of parametric insurance.
So this is insurance.
It's like an if-then.
Like if X happens, you get money and there's no filing process, no nothing.
So a lot of disaster insurance works this way.
But usually, like cities will get this.
Like, oh, oh, oh, oh, if there's an earthquake, you know, we just automatically get paid out.
So Ethereum is actually bringing this to everyday people.
So there's one very nice example I like is in Puerto Rico.
So in the case you don't know, Puerto Rico has had some trouble with hurricanes lately.
And so you can actually now buy hurricane insurance.
Puerto Ricos can now buy hurricane insurance such that if the National Weather Service
says wind speeds exceed some integer in your zip code, you just get paid in either
within a day and it's just done.
Now like this is cool.
And like you guys for other things, you probably just like flood insurance.
Like like monsoon insurance, all kinds of stuff.
This is new stuff.
All right, infrastructure.

And so basically it is physical ether.
I don't got anything but I can give them out to you here.

you get money.

So you can physically send assets.
There is some new stuff with cross chain compatibility with Ethereum Classic.
So there's this new project called the Peace Bridge.
And so in short, so the goal here is to have a plasma chain, which you've all heard of.
We have a dual roots.
We have one root on the ETC chain, one root on the ETH chain.
And they can both put deposits into the same chain.
And this provides a neutral ground where you can do atomic swaps.
And additionally, transactions from each chain become visible on the other.
This is neat.
And so this is a new thing we're playing with.

You say like, is five prime right here?
It turns it into a question here.
It turns into a code.
You can actually type this code directly.

You can ask, what is the price of gold on this date?
Oh, I didn't like that one.
All right.
You can invert a matrix.
So in short, so this is a Wolfram Alpha Oracle on Ethereum.
And you can just ask it all kinds of stuff.
And so there's a service called a -- sorry, service called rhombus.network that is currently
doing that.
So if you want to offload massive amounts of computation, like saying it is a number
prime or interpolated polynomial or all kinds of things, you can now do that.
Now there's another cool thing coming out.
So you've all probably heard of SGX.
So there's a new thing coming from Intel where you can turn the SGX into a hardware
wallet.
This is neat because it means that every Windows PC in the world is now a hardware wallet.
And so you can now trust -- you don't have to worry about getting owned anymore.
So you can now keep Ether on your own desktop without having to fumble around with a hardware
wallet.
So that's a new thing coming out shortly.
So this is the future.
So the future -- so there's a new project we're working on called a NeverSlash.
So the real problem with Proof of Stake is if you get owned, someone can cause your assets
to get slashed.
I mean, like they get destroyed.
So this NeverSlash thing, it is a Raspberry Pi that sits between you and a hardware wallet.
So if you're having a staking machine using Casper, you have a hardware wallet that you
stake on and you have your PC that's running the Ethereum node.
You put this Raspberry Pi from -- as a USB between your staking machine and your hardware
wallet.
And it looks at all of the votes going through.
And if it ever sees a vote that would cause you to get slashed, it just refuses to propagate
it.
Now this is really nice because as long as you have this thing plugged in, you don't get
slashed.
Period.
I mean, as long as I guess someone could physically come by.
But no.
And so basically even if you get owned, you still don't get slashed.
And I think this is one of the coolest things out there.
So there's one more project.
So I call it the Voluntary Back Doors.
So this is still upcoming.
So the idea is -- so this is probably the graceful fallback to the traditional legal
system.
So you've probably heard of Plasma and you've probably heard of -- it's also Substrate,
which is the new thing that was just announced at Web 3.
Basically, it allows you to create a brand new blockchain with your own defined rules.
So the idea is to create a new blockchain for every country on Earth.
And the rules are exactly the same as traditional Ethereum except it is back-dored by that government.
So the idea would be like say if I'm a Singaporean and you're like, I don't know, you're an American,
but for whatever reason we just love French courts.
I mean, you know, for whatever reason.
So instead of doing our contract on the big Ethereum chain, we can do it on the .fr Plasma
chain such that if anything terrible ever happened, we could then go to a French court
and say, hey, hey, hey, you know, you've got a key back there that would really help us
out.
So please use it.
Now the keys you can use, you can piggyback on the keys from the DNS sec infrastructure.
And that's how you get a key for every government.
So the government doesn't even have to be permission to do this.
You can just rope them in.
So because if there's like an example, like for every country, say .CZ for Czech Republic,
there is a key that says, is foo.CZ a legit name?
And you can just use that exact same key.
So yeah, that's a cool thing for voluntary back doors.
